abstract.p: First annual International Garden Festival is set to open this summer at Redford Gardens in Grand-Metis, Quebec, and will focus on avant-garde garden design (S)

block.p: The worlds of gardening and contemporary design meet this summer at the first annual International Garden Festival, held at the Reford Gardens in Grand-Metis, Quebec. Situated beside the St. Lawrence River on the scenic Gaspe Peninsula, Reford Gardens (also known by its French name, Les Jardins de Metis) is home to 3,000 varieties of indigenous and exotic plants.

With a focus on avant-garde garden design, the festival features living exhibitions created by nine landscape designers from Canada, the United States, France and Britain. Each garden -- they range from 2,100 to 4,300 square feet -- offers modern interpretations of cultivation and wilderness.

The worlds of gardening and contemporary design meet this summer at the first annual International Garden Festival, held at the Reford Gardens in Grand-Metis, Quebec. Situated beside the St. Lawrence River on the scenic Gaspe Peninsula, Reford Gardens (also known by its French name, Les Jardins de Metis) is home to 3,000 varieties of indigenous and exotic plants.

With a focus on avant-garde garden design, the festival features living exhibitions created by nine landscape designers from Canada, the United States, France and Britain. Each garden -- they range from 2,100 to 4,300 square feet -- offers modern interpretations of cultivation and wilderness.

For example, Susan Herrington's Surf and Turf, a neat row of potted exotic plants, recalls specimens brought from the colonies to stock early European gardens; in nearby beds the exotic plants thrive alongside native species. Marie-Chrystine Landry, a Quebec sculptor, spells out an S O S in artemisia and junipers.

Claude Cormier from Montreal eschews plants altogether in a modern rendering of a Victorian garden. In his Blue Stick Garden, 3,200 sticks stand in for perennials and hedges, their color reminiscent of the blue Himalayan poppies for which Reford Garden is renowned.

The International Garden Festival runs until Oct. 9, with workshops and lectures Aug. 18 to 26. Admission is $8, at $1.50 Canadian to the U.S. dollar. Information: (418) 775-2221, or visit www.refordgardens .com.
